benefits.title: Gastrointestinal Tolerance of Low, Medium and High Dose Acute Oral l-Glutamine Supplementation in Healthy Adults: A Pilot Study
benefits.summary: L-Glutamine supports gastrointestinal and immune function prior to catabolic stress, with most symptoms being mild.

benefits.title: Glutamine-enriched parenteral nutrition after autologous peripheral blood stem cell transplantation: effects on immune reconstitution and mucositis.
benefits.summary: Glutamine-enriched parenteral nutrition (GEPN) improves lymphocyte recovery after autologous peripheral blood stem cell transplantation and decreases mucositis severity.

benefits.title: Cellular Therapy
benefits.summary: Glutamine-enriched parenteral nutrition (GEPN) improves lymphocyte recovery after autologous peripheral blood stem cell transplantation (aPBSCT).

benefits.title: Why is L-glutamine metabolism important to cells of the immune system in health, postinjury, surgery or infection?
benefits.summary: Glutamine is essential for cell proliferation, acts as a respiratory fuel, and enhances the function of stimulated immune cells, such as lymphocytes, macrophages, and neutrophils.

benefits.title: Glutamine reduces heat shock-induced cell death in rat intestinal epithelial cells.
benefits.summary: Glutamine supplementation reduces heat shock-induced cell death and may play a key role in preventing intestinal mucosal atrophy.

benefits.title: The Emerging Role of l-Glutamine in Cardiovascular Health and Disease
benefits.summary: L-glutamine promotes cardiovascular health by optimizing nitric oxide synthesis, mitigating risk factors for cardiovascular disease, and protecting against cardiometabolic disease, ischemia-reperfusion injury, sickle cell disease, and heart failure.

benefits.title: Alanyl-glutamine and glutamine plus alanine supplements improve skeletal redox status in trained rats: involvement of heat shock protein pathways.
benefits.summary: Oral l-glutamine supplements can attenuate muscle damage and oxidative stress in high-intensity aerobic exercise by increasing heat shock proteins and heat shock factor 1.

benefits.title: Glutamine regulates the expression of proteins with a potential health‐promoting effect in human intestinal Caco‐2 cells
benefits.summary: Glutamine regulates the expression of proteins with potential health-promoting effects in intestinal cells, potentially improving gut mucosal integrity and function.

benefits.title: The Metabolic Responses to L-Glutamine of Livers from Rats with Diabetes Types 1 and 2
benefits.summary: L-glutamine infusion accelerates glucose output in type 1 diabetic rats, but type 2 diabetic rats show no accelerated glucose output but increased L-alanine production.

benefits.title: Pharmacokinetics of L-Glutamine (Endari) in Pediatric and Adult Sickle Cell Disease Patients: A Phase 4, Open-Label, Single-Center Study
benefits.summary: L-glutamine is approved by the FDA for the treatment of sickle cell disease, reducing painful episodes and hospitalizations.

side effects.title: Safety Profile of L-Glutamine in Patients with Sickle Cell Disease: Data from Post-Marketing Surveillance
side effects.summary: L-glutamine at approximately 0.3 g/kg twice daily is safe and well-tolerated, with common side effects including constipation, nausea, headache, abdominal pain, cough, pain in extremity, back pain, and chest pain.

side effects.title: Role of glutamine in bacterial transcytosis and epithelial cell injury.
side effects.summary: Glutamine deprivation in enterocytes leads to increased bacterial translocation and reduced epithelial cell resistance, potentially causing mucosal dysfunction and necrotic complications.
side effects.journal: JPEN. Journal of parenteral and enteral nutrition

side effects.title: Therapeutic considerations of L-glutamine: a review of the literature.
side effects.summary: L-glutamine may stimulate tumor growth and prevent gut and oral toxic side-effects in cancer chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
side effects.journal: Alternative medicine review : a journal of clinical therapeutic

side effects.title: Glutamine blockade induces divergent metabolic programs to overcome tumor immune evasion
side effects.summary: Blocking glutamine metabolism in cancer patients can result in decreased toxicity and enhanced anticancer immune responses.

side effects.title: Production, purification and kinetic characterization of glutaminase free anti-leukemic L-asparaginase with low endotoxin level from novel soil isolate
side effects.summary: L-asparaginase side effects are attributed to glutaminase activity, which is toxic to non-tumor cells and endotoxin content, which can produce vasoactive amines and induce septic shock.

side effects.title: Reduction of chemotherapy-induced side-effects by parenteral glutamine supplementation in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer.
side effects.summary: Parenteral glutamine supplementation reduces chemotherapy-induced mucositis and ulcerations in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer.

side effects.title: Control of Nitrate Uptake by Phloem‐Translocated Glutamine in Zea mays L. Seedlings
side effects.summary: Glutamine treatment in Zea mays seedlings resulted in a strong inhibition of nitrate uptake rate and a significant enrichment of amino compounds in root tissue.

side effects.title: The differential ability of asparagine and glutamine in promoting the closed/active enzyme conformation rationalizes the Wolinella succinogenes L-asparaginase substrate specificity
side effects.summary: L-glutaminase activity is related to side effects of current FDA-approved L-asparaginases, and the Wolinella succinogenes L-asparaginase variant with a proline at position 121 has L-glutaminase activity.

side effects.title: Risk Assessment of "Other Substances" – L-Glutamine and L-glutamic Acid
side effects.summary: L-glutamine and L-glutamic acid are considered non-essential amino acids in humans and play important roles in protein synthesis, central nervous system, immune system, and insulin secretion.

side effects.title: Excitatory Amino Acid Neurotransmitters in the Corticostriate Pathway: Studies Using Intracerebral Microdialysis In Vivo
side effects.summary: Glutamine is the principal precursor for neurotransmitter glutamate in the corticostriate pathway.

dosage.title: Gastrointestinal Tolerance of Low, Medium and High Dose Acute Oral l-Glutamine Supplementation in Healthy Adults: A Pilot Study
dosage.summary: Acute oral l-glutamine ingestion in dosages up to 0.9 gkgFFM1 are generally well-tolerated, but the severity of mild gastrointestinal symptoms appears dose-dependent during the first two hours post prandial.

dosage.title: Dosing and efficacy of glutamine supplementation in human exercise and sport training.
dosage.summary: Acute intakes of 20-30g of glutamine seem to be without ill effect in healthy adult humans, and doses of up to 0.65g/kg body mass have been reported to be tolerated.

dosage.title: The pharmacokinetic responses of humans to 20 g of alanyl-glutamine dipeptide differ with the dosing protocol but not with gastric acidity or in patients with acute Dengue fever.
dosage.summary: Oral administration of 20g of L-alanyl-glutamine (Ala-Gln) significantly increased free plasma Gln and alanine concentrations in healthy subjects.

dosage.title: Pharmacokinetics of L-Glutamine (Endari) in Pediatric and Adult Sickle Cell Disease Patients: A Phase 4, Open-Label, Single-Center Study
dosage.summary: L-glutamine doses in this study were 0.1 g/kg, 0.3 g/kg twice daily, and 0.6 g/kg once daily.

dosage.title: Effects of enteral supplementation with glutamine granules on intestinal mucosal barrier function in severe burned patients.
dosage.summary: Glutamine granules taken orally at a dosage of 0.5 g/kg for 14 days can abate intestinal injury, lessen intestinal mucosal permeability, ameliorate wound healing, and reduce hospital stay.
dosage.journal: Burns : journal of the International Society for Burn Injuries

dosage.title: L-glutamine absorption is enhanced after ingestion of L-alanylglutamine compared with the free amino acid or wheat protein.
dosage.summary: Ingestion of 60 mg/kg of L-glutamine, 89 mg/kg of Sustamine, or 200 mg/kg of hydrolyzed wheat protein resulted in significant increases in plasma L-glutamine concentrations.

dosage.title: Safety and metabolic effects of L-glutamine administration in humans.
dosage.summary: Oral doses of L-glutamine range from 0 to 0.3 g/kg, and intravenous administration is well tolerated at doses of 0.0125 and 0.025 g/kg/hr.
dosage.journal: JPEN. Journal of parenteral and enteral nutrition

dosage.title: L-Glutamine therapy reduces endothelial adhesion of sickle red blood cells to human umbilical vein endothelial cells
dosage.summary: Oral L-glutamine administration at a dosage of 30 grams per day improves sickle RBC adhesion to human umbilical vein endothelial cells.

dosage.title: Administration of glutamine and its dipeptides in parenteral nutrition. Which patients are candidates
dosage.summary: The dose of L-glutamine or its dipeptide forms in post-operative periods is 0.19-0.29 g/kg/day, and in patients undergoing bone marrow transplants, 0.37-0.57 g/kg/day.
